DOC.TEXT: Stock prices showed a modest loss today, registering no strong reaction to the U.S. military action in Panama. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 5.34 to 2,690.27 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 529 up, 699 down and 550 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 55.75 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said investors were cautiously watching the situation in Panama, but apparently not viewing it as any cause to make big changes in their strategies. They noted that the prospective economic effects of the confrontation, if any, remained unclear. At the same time, brokers said, stock traders appeared to draw only brief encouragement from an upward revision in the latest government figures on economic growth. The Commerce Department said the gross national product grew at a 3.0 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the third quarter of the year, up from a previous estimate of 2.7 percent. But traders said projections remained gloomy for the results to be posted in the fourth quarter and the early stages of 1990. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris rose [ to 40{; International Business Machines dropped | to 94[; American Express gained ] to 31], and McDonald's was down \ at 33\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dipped .18 to 189.22. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .61 at 367.34.
